head.title: Planes Can Fly on Time, if the Airlines Try

hedline.hl1: Planes Can Fly on Time, if the Airlines Try

abstract.p: Ken Niemi letter comments on August 21 article on scheduling problems plaguing airlines; drawing

block.p: Substantially improving the on-time performance of the airline industry is not rocket science (news article, Aug. 21).
Substantially improving the on-time performance of the airline industry is not rocket science (news article, Aug. 21).
The fundamental problem is that during peak periods of the day, the airlines are scheduling more flights than can be handled while providing 90 percent on-time performance.

The short-term solution is to have each airport determine how many flights can be handled safely with 90 percent on-time performance during each hour of the day, for each month, given typical weather.
If the number of flights desired by airlines exceeded that number, airlines could bid for the right to a landing or take-off slot, with the proceeds used to improve the air-traffic control system.
There is an equally simple solution to the shortage of skilled pilots and the inability of most busy airports to expand: airlines must use larger planes and then schedule fewer flights.
